author: Camille George
title: Sécheresse, il y a péril en la demeure - L'Agefi
text: Le problème du manque d’eau reste intimement lié au changement climatique. Et sur ce point, les épisodes de sécheresse répétés sont la cause de bien des dégâts, notamment sur l’habitat. Les conséquences parfois dramatiques sur la valeur des biens mettent le système assurantiel à rude épreuve. Un évènement L’AGEFI PRIVATE EQUITY FRANCE 2 avril 2024 à 2:00 PM S’inscrire Plus d'articles du même thème - Ces entreprises que l’intelligence artificielle pourrait faire disparaitre L’avènement de l’IA générative promet de bouleverser de nombreux secteurs d’activités. Au point que certaines entreprises particulièrement exposées commencent déjà à subir la défiance des investisseurs. - Franck Le Vallois, l'ex directeur général de France Assureurs, prend la tête d'Aon France Le courtier revoit son organisation en Europe. Laurent Belhout, qui occupait le poste de PDG France depuis 14 ans, prend de nouvelles fonctions dans ce cadre. - Les assureurs français, aux commandes de 2.552 milliards d'euros d'actifs Deux tiers du portefeuille des assureurs financent les entreprises avec une percée du private equity, du crédit et des infrastructures. Sujets d'actualité Tous les sujets ETF à la Une BlackRock lance à son tour des ETF actifs en Europe Ces deux véhicules listés s’appuient sur une méthodologie propriétaire qui mêle machine learning, big data et intervention humaine. Les plus lus - La BCE inflige une amende de 3,5 millions au groupe Crédit Mutuel - Avec son école de la banque, BNP Paribas prépare la relève dans son réseau - Le coup de force d’Altice chamboule le marché de la dette à haut rendement - Le directeur général d’Axa est mieux payé que les patrons de banques françaises - L’ex-Orpea se remet dans le bon sens avec son regroupement d’actions Contenu de nos partenaires A lire sur ... - Trois jours avant l’attentat à Moscou, Poutine affirmait que les avertissements des Etats-Unis relevaient du «chantage» Au début du mois de mars, la Russie avait été avertie par Washington d’une possible attaque contre de « grands rassemblements » - Chausses-trappes Les Républicains: François-Xavier Bellamy dans le viseur des planqués de la campagne des européennes Ils sont plusieurs, au sein du parti, à souhaiter un échec en juin de la tête de liste LR aux européennes pour ensuite passer à l'offensive - Crash de la voiture électrique sur le mur de la pensée magique Le replay de «Voyage en absurdie», la chronique matinale d’Emmanuelle Ducros sur Europe 1

author: ACC Digital Network
title: Ven-Allen Lubin 2024-25 Regular Season Highlights | North Carolina Forward
text:
Ven-Allen Lubin 2024-25 Regular Season Highlights | North Carolina Forward
North Carolina forward Ven-Allen Lubin turned out to be a big get out of the transfer portal for the Tar Heels during the 2024-25. Lubin finished the season averaging 8.6 points per game, a team-high 5.6 rebounds and 0.9 blocks while shooting 67.7% from the floor. Lubin emerged as the go-to guy on the inside for Carolina as the season progressed, as the team had to replace the huge production that was lost with the departure of Armando Bacot. Enjoy this look at the best plays Ven-Allen Lubin made for the Tar Heels brought to you by the ACC Digital...
Read more at www.youtube.com

author: Jaxx Liberty
title: Comment on The Science Is Never Settled: Climate Change and The Scientific Method by Jaxx Liberty
text:
by 1776
In September of 2011, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist, Ivar Giaever, resigned from the American Physical Society. The APS’s position on “climate change” was one he could no longer accept – to wit, APS’s use of the word “incontrovertible” to describe the evidence in favor of global warming.
This seemingly innocuous word caused so much contention within the APS, that their leadership was eventually forced to create a special working group to address it. The transcripts from one of the workshops ran over 570 pages. Clearly, this was no mere triviality.
After much wrangling and debate, the APS leadership finally relented and removed the offending term from their official position statement on climate change.
To the uninitiated, a battle over one word may seem overwrought. But to those in the know, it was a contest for the heart and soul of science because the word incontrovertible runs totally contrary to the essential elements of science, i.e., skepticism, inquiry, reproducibility, falsifiability, etc.
Put another way, nothing in science is technically “incontrovertible”, and the science is never really “settled”. A scientist does not set out to “prove” a hypothesis; rather, they attempt to falsify it through experimentation. And if the hypothesis withstands an attempt at falsification, confidence in it grows. But that confidence never passes the threshold of being incontrovertible. The reason for this is simple: It’s always possible that the next experiment will end up falsifying the hypothesis.
In this way, science seeks to provide useful models for describing and explaining the natural world while acknowledging the inherent limitations on human knowledge along with the uncertainties that come with it. Words like incontrovertible and settled are attempts to brush aside that uncertainty and to supplant it with a set of unscientific dogmas.
Judith Curry, a career climatologist at Georgia Tech, found this out the hard way.
An erstwhile proponent of man-made global warming, Curry eventually transitioned into the skeptic camp. She never stopped believing that humans have an effect on climate generally or the earth’s temperature specifically, however she began to question the degree of confidence that some scientists were attributing to man’s role in warming the planet. In any other scientific context, this would have been unremarkable. But in the highly politicized environment of “climate science”, it resulted in an onslaught that eventually forced her to resign from her position. Curry explains on her blog:
A deciding factor was that I no longer know what to say to students and postdocs regarding how to navigate the CRAZINESS in the field of climate science. Research and other professional activities are professionally rewarded only if they are channeled in certain directions approved by a politicized academic establishment — funding, ease of getting your papers published, getting hired in prestigious positions, appointments to prestigious committees and boards, professional recognition, etc.
How young scientists are to navigate all this is beyond me, and it often becomes a battle of scientific integrity versus career suicide (I have worked through these issues with a number of skeptical young scientists).
Let me relate an interaction that I had with a postdoc about a month ago. She wanted to meet me, as an avid reader of my blog. She works in a field that is certainly relevant to climate science, but she doesn’t identify as a climate scientist. She says she gets questioned all the time about global warming issues, and doesn’t know what to say, since topics like attribution, etc. are not topics that she explores as a scientist. WOW, a scientist that knows the difference! I advised her to keep her head down and keep doing the research that she thinks interesting and important, and to stay out of the climate debate UNLESS she decides to dig in and pursue it intellectually. Personal opinions about the science and political opinions about policies that are sort of related to your research expertise are just that – personal and political opinions. Selling such opinions as contributing to a scientific consensus is very much worse than a joke.
Curry’s climate apostasy has not won her many friends in the academic community:
In a field where inquiry, skepticism, and robust debate should be welcomed and encouraged, the high priests of man-made global warming have declared the discussion over. All who deviate from the prevailing orthodoxy are stigmatized as heretics and shills. Meanwhile, a veritable army of politically motivated authoritarians perpetuate and reinforce these articles of faith for transparently self-serving reasons. The only thing standing in their way… is science.

author: Pongrass Import
title: LETTER: Disturbance of peace in West Village, where are the cops?
text:
Letters Local news
LETTER: Disturbance of peace in West Village, where are the cops?
A West Village resident writes a letter about why cops do nothing when there is a disturbance of peace.
• Chris Schoonwinkel writes:
Dear Station Commander of Krugersdorp Police Station.
West Village was under siege on Saturday night, April 13, by a ‘religious’ group who presumably played a recording of African drums very loud, right through the night. Between midnight and 01:00 on April 14, I called Krugersdorp police three times without anyone picking up.
ALSO READ:
LETTER: Stop promoting land grabs
I then called 10111 where I did complain about the noise and they took up my complaint and sent out an officer who investigated this matter.
He called me and told me that the offenders are busy with a ‘ceremony’ and there is nothing he can do. West Village is a residential suburb and the noise was very disturbing to residents.
Now I want to know whether ‘ceremonies’ are above the law. Or is it the other way around? Seeing that the officer said that he couldn’t do anything about it.
I would appreciate it if you would look into this matter and let me know what your views on this matter are.
ALSO READ:
LETTER: Water crisis: What’s really going on?
West Rand District Police spokesperson Captain Solomon Sibiya responded to Schoonwinkel’s conversation with Lt Col Moabelo regarding his complaint.
“No ceremony is above the law. We have looked into the matter and taken appropriate internal corrective measures to make sure that it does not happen in the future.”

author: J. Arias Borque
title: Margarita Robles confirma que Ucrania tiene ya en su poder los misiles Patriot enviados por España
text:
El conjunto de misiles antiaéreos Patriot que España se comprometió a enviar al Gobierno de Kiev como parte de un nuevo paquete de ayuda militar ya se encuentran en suelo ucraniano. A partir de ahora formará parte del stock que proyectiles con el que cuentan las autoridades del país eslavo para protegerse de los ataques aéreos que Rusia lanza de forma cotidiana contra zonas clave y estratégicas de Ucrania .
Así lo ha confirmado este lunes la ministra de Defensa, Margarita Robles , durante su visita a las instalaciones del Regimiento de Pontoneros y Especialidades de Ingenieros nº 12 (RPEI-12) del Ejército de Tierra y al Hospital General de la Defensa ‘Orad y Gajías’, en Zaragoza, donde se atiende y se practican cirugías complejas a algunos de los militares ucranianos que son heridos en el frente de batalla.
"Un grupo de misiles Patriot ha llegado ya a Ucrania . Llegó la pasado semana. Nosotros obviamente en esto trabajamos coordinadamente con nuestros aliados porque entendemos que Ucrania está defendiendo su integridad, está defendiendo vidas humanas. Eso misiles son misiles para defensa antiaérea , eso tiene que quedar muy claro, son misiles para defenderse de los ataques que están sufriendo", ha dicho la titular de Defensa.
Relacionado Rusia emite una orden de busca y captura contra el presidente de Ucrania La quincena de Programas Especiales de Armamento que centran la modernización del Ejército de Tierra Del Báltico a Rumanía: así es el despliegue de las Fuerzas Armadas españoles en la Europa del Este España enviará misiles Patriot a Ucrania presionada por la OTAN y la UE, pero no las lanzaderas ni otros componentes "Rusia está utilizando incluso bombas de racimo y todo tipo de material contra la población civil. Ese envío que hemos hecho coordinadamente con nuestros aliados ha llegado ya y lo único que puedo decir es que tienen una capacidad defensiva para proteger a la población ucraniana ", ha continuado Margarita Robles.
El envío está dentro de los compromisos adquiridos por España en la última reunión del Grupo de Contacto para la Defensa de Ucrania (UDCG, por sus siglas en inglés), después de la fuerte presión recibida tanto por los socios de la OTAN como de la Unión Europea durante semanas, en las que el Gobierno español intentó mirar hacia otro lado y no entregar un material que considera esencial para su propia defensa.
De hecho, sólo se han enviado los misiles en sí , un número exacto no hecho público por el Ministerio de Defensa, con un coste cada uno de ellos cercano al millón de euros, para que sean empleados por baterías antiaéreas Patriot donadas por otros países aliados, puesto que España no ha entregado ni las lanzaderas ni los otros componentes que completan este sistema (estación de control de empeño, planta suministrado de energía o el radar).
Los ucranianos tienen en estos momentos tres baterías Patriot para defender su territorio nacional en una cota media-alta. De esas tres baterías, dos han sido donadas por Alemania y otra por Estados Unidos. De la última reunión aliada, celebrada en Ramstein, salió el compromiso de Alemania y Estados Unidos de ceder más baterías completas . Querían que España donara otra, pero se han tenido que conformar con los misiles enviados.
Temas Fuerzas Armadas de España Margarita Robles Ucrania Guerra Rusia Ucrania
